open_questions.title: Kubernetes
open_questions.description: What is Kubernetes?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is Kubernetes?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Kubernetes is an open-source platform designed to automate deploying, scaling, and operating application containers. It groups containers that make up an application into logical units for easy management and discovery. Kubernetes is widely used for managing containerized applications across a cluster of machines, with support for high availability, load balancing, self-healing, and automated rollouts and rollbacks.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: K8s
open_questions.description: What are K8s?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are K8s?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: K8s is the shorthand notation for Kubernetes, derived by replacing the eight letters of "ubernete" with the digit "8". Kubernetes is an open-source platform for automating deployment, scaling, and operations of application containers across clusters of hosts.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.description: What is orchestration?

Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Orchestration, in the context of computing, refers to the automated management, arrangement, and coordination of complex computer systems, applications, and services. It's commonly used in cloud environments to efficiently manage and scale distributed applications and workloads.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The components of a Kubernetes cluster
open_questions.description: Explain the components of a Kubernetes cluster and their roles.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the components of a Kubernetes cluster and their roles.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Kubernetes clusters consist of: Master Node: Central control plane that manages the cluster's state and configuration. Key components include: API Server: Gateway for Kubernetes API and cluster management. etcd: Key-value store for cluster data. Scheduler: Assigns work, like pods, to nodes. Controller Manager: Manages controllers that regulate the state of the cluster. Worker Nodes: Machines that run applications using containers. Key components include: Kubelet: Agent that ensures containers are running in a pod. Kube-Proxy: Manages network communication between pods and external traffic. Container Runtime: Software for running containers (e.g., Docker). Pods: Smallest deployable units, containers in a node are encapsulated in Pods. Services and Ingress: Manage network access to the pods, providing stable IP addresses and load balancing. ConfigMaps and Secrets: Store configuration data and sensitive information, used by pods. Volumes: Provide storage resources to pods, persistent or ephemeral. Namespaces: Divide cluster resources between multiple users via virtual clusters.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The Master Node in Kubernetes.
open_questions.description: Explain the Master Node in Kubernetes.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the Master Node in Kubernetes.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The Master Node in Kubernetes is the central control plane that manages the state and configuration of the cluster. It has several key components: API Server: Serves as the front-end for the Kubernetes control plane, handling internal and external requests. etcd: A consistent and highly-available key-value store used as Kubernetes' backing store for all cluster data. Scheduler: Assigns work, typically in the form of pods, to worker nodes based on resource availability. Controller Manager: Runs controller processes, which regulate the state of the cluster, managing things like node status, pod replication, and endpoint creation. Cloud Controller Manager: Optional, integrates the cluster with cloud provider-specific features.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The Worker Node in Kubernetes.
open_questions.description: Explain the Worker Node in Kubernetes.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the Worker Node in Kubernetes.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In Kubernetes, a Worker Node is responsible for running containers and executing the workloads assigned to it by the Master Node. Key components: Kubelet: The Kubelet is an agent running on each Worker Node. It communicates with the Master Node and ensures that containers are running in pods as specified in the cluster's desired state. It manages container lifecycle operations, such as starting, stopping, and monitoring containers. Container Runtime: The Container Runtime (e.g., Docker, containerd, or CRI-O) is responsible for actually running containers and managing their execution. It takes container specifications provided by the Kubelet and runs the containers accordingly. Kube Proxy: Kube Proxy is a network proxy that runs on each Worker Node. It maintains network rules on the node to enable communication between pods and services within the cluster. It helps in load balancing traffic to the appropriate pods. Pod: Pods are the smallest deployable units in Kubernetes. Each Worker Node can run one or more pods, and each pod can contain one or more containers that share the same network namespace. Containers within the same pod can communicate with each other using localhost, making it easier to manage related processes. CNI (Container Network Interface): CNI plugins are responsible for setting up the network connectivity for pods on the Worker Node. They ensure that pods can communicate with each other and with the external network as needed. Container Storage Interface (CSI): This component allows Kubernetes pods to interact with external storage systems, providing a way to mount storage volumes into containers when required.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The Kubelet in Kubernetes.
open_questions.description: Explain the Kubelet in Kubernetes.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the Kubelet in Kubernetes.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The Kubelet is a fundamental component in Kubernetes, running on each worker node. It has several key responsibilities: Pod Management: Ensures that containers in pods are running and healthy as specified in the PodSpec (the desired state). Node Registration: Registers each node with the cluster, making them available for scheduling and running pods. Resource Monitoring: Monitors the resource usage of pods and reports back to the master node. Lifecycle Management: Handles the lifecycle events of the container, such as starting, stopping, and restarting. Health Checks: Performs regular health checks to ensure that containers are operating correctly. Communicating with API Server: Receives instructions from the master node and sends operational data about the node and its pods back to the API Server. Volume Management: Manages storage volumes as defined by the pod configuration and ensures these are attached to and accessible by the right containers. Executing Control Loops: Continuously works in a control loop to ensure the actual state of the node's pods matches the desired state defined in the Kubernetes API.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The Kube-proxy in Kubernetes.
open_questions.description: Explain the Kube-proxy in Kubernetes.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the Kube-proxy in Kubernetes.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The Kube-proxy in Kubernetes is a network proxy that runs on each worker node, facilitating network communication to and from pods. It manages the Kubernetes networking services on the node, ensuring that network traffic can be directed to the correct pods and providing basic load balancing. Kube-proxy updates the node's network rules – such as iptables or IPVS rules – to route traffic, handles service discovery, and maintains network connectivity for the pods.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The API Server in Kubernetes.
open_questions.description: Explain the API Server in Kubernetes.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the API Server in Kubernetes.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The API Server in Kubernetes is the central component of the Kubernetes control plane, serving as the primary interface for all cluster operations. It processes RESTful requests, validates them, updates the corresponding objects in etcd (Kubernetes' database), and provides a frontend to the cluster's shared state. The API Server is the only component that interacts directly with etcd, ensuring a consistent and reliable view of the cluster data. It's designed for horizontal scalability and is the hub for all internal and external communications in the cluster.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The Controller Manager in Kubernetes.
open_questions.description: Explain the Controller Manager in Kubernetes.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the Controller Manager in Kubernetes.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The Controller Manager in Kubernetes is a component of the master node that manages various controllers, which are background processes that regulate the state of the cluster. These controllers include the Node Controller (overseeing node health), Replication Controller (managing pod replicas), Endpoints Controller (populating endpoints objects), and Service Account & Token Controllers (creating default accounts and API access tokens for new namespaces). The Controller Manager watches the cluster's shared state through the API server and makes changes to move the current state towards the desired state.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A Pod in Kubernetes, and why
open_questions.description: What is a Pod in Kubernetes, and why is it the smallest deployable unit?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a Pod in Kubernetes, and why is it the smallest deployable unit?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Pod in Kubernetes is the smallest and simplest deployable unit that can be created and managed. It represents a single instance of an application and can contain one or more containers (such as Docker containers). The reason it's considered the smallest unit is that it encapsulates the application's container(s), storage resources, a unique network IP, and options that govern how the container(s) should run. Pods are designed to be ephemeral and disposable, which aligns with the Kubernetes model of handling instances of applications. Each pod is meant to run a single instance of a given application; when it needs to scale, Kubernetes creates more pods, rather than using single containers as the unit of scaling.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The differences between Kubernetes and Docker
open_questions.description: What are the differences between Kubernetes and Docker?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the differences between Kubernetes and Docker?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Kubernetes is a container orchestrator for managing complex, distributed systems, offering features like automatic deployment, scaling, and load balancing. Docker, on the other hand, is a container runtime focused on building and running individual containers. Docker is simpler and commonly used in development, while Kubernetes handles larger-scale, production-grade deployments and integrates with various cloud services.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The main differences between the Docker
open_questions.description: What are the main differences between the Docker Swarm and Kubernetes?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the main differences between the Docker Swarm and Kubernetes?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Complexity and Setup: Docker Swarm is simpler to set up and use, while Kubernetes is more complex but offers more features and flexibility. Scalability: Kubernetes is more robust in handling large clusters and more complex applications compared to Docker Swarm. High Availability: Kubernetes provides more sophisticated high availability features than Docker Swarm. Ecosystem and Community: Kubernetes has a larger ecosystem and community support, with more tools and extensions available. Load Balancing: Kubernetes offers more advanced load balancing and can handle more complex networking. Stateful Applications: Kubernetes better supports stateful applications with features like StatefulSets and Persistent Volumes.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of Kubernetes Labels and
open_questions.description: Explain the purpose of Kubernetes Labels and Selectors.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the purpose of Kubernetes Labels and Selectors.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Kubernetes Labels are key-value pairs attached to objects (like pods) for identification and organization. Selectors are queries used to identify objects based on their labels. This mechanism allows for efficient grouping, management, and selection of objects within a Kubernetes cluster, facilitating operations like deploying, updating, and filtering resources based on specific criteria.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Heapster was a performance monitoring and metrics collection system in Kubernetes, aggregating resource usage information across a cluster. It has since been deprecated and replaced by more advanced tools like Metrics Server and Prometheus for resource monitoring and metrics gathering.

open_questions.title: A Kubernetes Deployment
open_questions.description: What is a Kubernetes Deployment?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a Kubernetes Deployment?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Kubernetes Deployment is a resource that provides declarative updates to applications, allowing you to describe the desired state for your application's pods and replicas. It enables automated pod management (creation, deletion, updating) and scaling, ensuring that a specified number of pod replicas are running at any given time. Deployments are ideal for stateless applications and are used for rolling updates and rollbacks.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of Persistent Volumes (PVs)
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of Persistent Volumes (PVs) and Persistent Volume Claims (PVCs) in Kubernetes.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of Persistent Volumes (PVs) and Persistent Volume Claims (PVCs) in Kubernetes.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Persistent Volumes (PVs) in Kubernetes are storage resources in a cluster, used to manage durable storage that persists beyond the lifecycle of individual pods. Persistent Volume Claims (PVCs) are requests for storage by users, specifying size, and access modes. PVCs are matched with appropriate PVs in the cluster, decoupling the specifics of storage provisioning from its use by pods, allowing consistent storage access regardless of the underlying storage infrastructure.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Mention some key differences between Kubernetes
open_questions.description: Mention some key differences between Kubernetes Volumes and Docker Volumes .?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Mention some key differences between Kubernetes Volumes and Docker Volumes .?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Scope: Kubernetes volumes are tied to the lifecycle of a pod, while Docker volumes are independent of the container's lifecycle. Management: Kubernetes handles volume management at the pod level, providing more complex strategies (like PersistentVolumes), while Docker's volume management is more container-centric. Integration: Kubernetes volumes integrate with various storage backends and are part of a broader orchestration system, whereas Docker volumes are more focused on simplicity and ease of use for individual containers.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: List some of the types of
open_questions.description: List some of the types of Kubernetes volumes.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "List some of the types of Kubernetes volumes.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: emptyDir: A temporary directory that shares a pod's lifetime, useful for temporary storage. hostPath: Maps a file or directory from the host node's filesystem into a pod, used for specific node-level storage. nfs: Mounts an NFS (Network File System) share into a pod, useful for integrating existing NFS-based storage. persistentVolumeClaim: Allows a pod to use a Persistent Volume, ideal for long-term and cross-pod storage. configMap: Used to inject configuration data into pods, allowing you to keep containers agnostic of configuration details. secret: Used to pass sensitive information like passwords and keys to pods, ensuring secure handling of confidential data. azureDisk: Integrates Azure-managed disk as a volume, suitable for Azure-hosted Kubernetes clusters. awsElasticBlockStore: Mounts AWS EBS (Elastic Block Store) volumes into pods, ideal for AWS-based persistent storage. gcePersistentDisk: Attaches Google Compute Engine persistent disks to pods, for GCE-based persistent storage. csi (Container Storage Interface): Enables using various external storage systems in a standardized way, allowing for greater flexibility and vendor agnosticism.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A Kubernetes StatefulSet, and in what
open_questions.description: What is a Kubernetes StatefulSet, and in what scenarios would you use it?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a Kubernetes StatefulSet, and in what scenarios would you use it?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Kubernetes StatefulSet is a workload API object used for managing stateful applications. It manages the deployment and scaling of a set of Pods and provides guarantees about the ordering and uniqueness of these Pods. Unlike a Deployment, a StatefulSet maintains a sticky identity for each of their Pods. It's used in scenarios where you need stable, unique network identifiers, stable, persistent storage, and ordered, graceful deployment and scaling. This makes it suitable for applications like databases, clustered applications, and any other application that requires stable state or unique identity.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Horizontal Pod Autoscaling in Kubernetes.
open_questions.description: Explain Horizontal Pod Autoscaling in Kubernetes.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain Horizontal Pod Autoscaling in Kubernetes.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Horizontal Pod Autoscaling in Kubernetes automatically scales the number of pods in a deployment, replica set, or stateful set based on observed CPU utilization or other select metrics. It increases or decreases the count of pod replicas to meet the current demand, ensuring efficient resource utilization and handling of workload changes.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Kubernetes ConfigMaps and Secrets
open_questions.description: What are Kubernetes ConfigMaps and Secrets?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are Kubernetes ConfigMaps and Secrets?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Kubernetes ConfigMaps and Secrets are resources used to store configuration data and sensitive information, respectively. ConfigMaps allow you to separate configuration artifacts from image content, reducing the risk of exposing confidential data when configuring containers. Secrets provide a mechanism to hold sensitive information, such as passwords, OAuth tokens, and SSH keys, using a more secure and controlled means than regular configuration data.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A Kubernetes Operator
open_questions.description: What is a Kubernetes Operator?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a Kubernetes Operator?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Kubernetes Operator is a software extension that automates the management of complex, stateful applications in Kubernetes. It encapsulates human operational knowledge in code to handle tasks like deployment, updates, and maintenance, reducing manual intervention and increasing efficiency and reliability. Operators are particularly useful for applications requiring specific, detailed management procedures.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of Kubernetes namespaces.
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of Kubernetes namespaces.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of Kubernetes namespaces.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Kubernetes namespaces are a way to divide cluster resources between multiple users and projects. They provide a scope for names, allowing the same resource types in different namespaces without conflict. Namespaces are useful for environments with many users across multiple teams or projects, as they enable resource organization, access control, and resource quota management.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: You use custom namespaces
open_questions.description: Why should you use custom namespaces ?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Why should you use custom namespaces ?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Custom namespaces in Kubernetes are used for organizing and isolating resources within a cluster, aiding in access control, resource sharing, and managing limits on resource usage. This is particularly useful in environments with multiple teams or projects to prevent conflicts and improve clarity.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Kubernetes liveness and readiness probes
open_questions.description: What are Kubernetes liveness and readiness probes?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are Kubernetes liveness and readiness probes?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Kubernetes liveness and readiness probes are mechanisms to manage container health. Liveness probes determine if a container is running properly, restarting it if the check fails. Readiness probes assess if a container is ready to handle requests, affecting traffic routing to the container.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Kubernetes Network Policies.
open_questions.description: Explain Kubernetes Network Policies.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain Kubernetes Network Policies.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Kubernetes Network Policies are rules that govern how pods communicate with each other and other network endpoints. They provide a way to configure network access control, specifying which pods can communicate and how data can flow between them. This enhances security by enforcing restrictions on inbound and outbound pod traffic.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is Kube-proxy?" open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Kube-proxy is a network proxy component in each Kubernetes node that manages the node's network rules and handles communication between pods and external users, ensuring efficient pod networking.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Node port
open_questions.description: Explain node port?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain node port?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In Kubernetes, a NodePort is a type of service that exposes a pod to external traffic on a static port on each node’s IP address. NodePort allows external clients to access a service on a stable port, making it suitable for scenarios where specific port assignments are necessary.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: How Kubernetes handles rolling back a
open_questions.description: Explain how Kubernetes handles rolling back a failed deployment and maintaining application availability.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain how Kubernetes handles rolling back a failed deployment and maintaining application availability.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Kubernetes handles rolling back a failed deployment by automatically reverting to the previous stable version of the application. This rollback happens if it detects a failure during a deployment update. Kubernetes ensures application availability by incrementally updating pods with new versions and simultaneously monitoring health checks. If an issue arises, it stops the rollout and rolls back, minimizing downtime and maintaining service continuity.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Can you explain Kubernetes' concept of
open_questions.description: Can you explain Kubernetes' concept of affinity and anti-affinity rules and how they affect Pod scheduling?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Can you explain Kubernetes' concept of affinity and anti-affinity rules and how they affect Pod scheduling?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Kubernetes' affinity and anti-affinity rules allow you to influence where pods are scheduled based on labels on other pods. Affinity rules attract pods to nodes with specific characteristics, while anti-affinity rules repel them, helping to spread or co-locate pods across different nodes for various reasons like performance, availability, or resource utilization.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A Kubernetes Service, and why is
open_questions.description: What is a Kubernetes Service, and why is it needed?

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Kubernetes Service is an abstract way to expose an application running on a set of Pods as a network service. It provides a stable IP address and DNS name for accessing Pods, ensuring that applications remain accessible even as Pods are scaled up or down.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between a Kubernetes Service
open_questions.description: What is the difference between a Kubernetes Service and an Ingress resource?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between a Kubernetes Service and an Ingress resource?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Kubernetes Service provides internal load balancing and network access to a set of pods within a cluster. An Ingress resource, on the other hand, manages external access to the services, typically HTTP/HTTPS, providing features like host or URL-based routing, SSL termination, and name-based virtual hosting.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A Kubernetes DaemonSet
open_questions.description: What is a Kubernetes DaemonSet?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a Kubernetes DaemonSet?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Kubernetes DaemonSet ensures that a copy of a Pod runs on all (or a subset of) nodes in the cluster. It's typically used for background tasks or system-level agents that need to run on every node, such as log collectors, monitoring agents, or storage solutions.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: How rolling updates work in Kubernetes
open_questions.description: Explain how rolling updates work in Kubernetes Deployments.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain how rolling updates work in Kubernetes Deployments.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In Kubernetes, rolling updates gradually replace pods of the previous version of an application with the new version without downtime. The Deployment updates pods in a controlled way, creating new pods and deleting old ones, while maintaining application availability. This process ensures zero-downtime deployments and allows for easy rollback if needed.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of the Kubernetes Service
open_questions.description: What is the purpose of the Kubernetes Service object?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the purpose of the Kubernetes Service object?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Kubernetes Service is an abstraction that defines a set of Pods and a policy for accessing them. It allows Pods to communicate with each other and with external clients using a stable IP address and DNS name. Services can be used for load balancing, service discovery, and exposing applications within or outside the cluster.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Kubernetes RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) and
open_questions.description: Explain Kubernetes RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) and its significance in cluster security.?

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Kubernetes RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) is a method for regulating access to Kubernetes API resources based on the roles of individual users or processes within your organization. It helps enforce security and compliance by ensuring that only authorized users have access to specific resources and operations in the Kubernetes cluster.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Between a replica set and a
open_questions.description: Differentiate between a replica set and a replication controller.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Differentiate between a replica set and a replication controller.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Replica Set in Kubernetes is the next-generation iteration of the Replication Controller. Both ensure a specified number of pod replicas are running at any given time. The key difference is that Replica Sets support a broader and more expressive set of pod selection capabilities with their selector functionality, whereas Replication Controllers are limited to equality-based selector requirements. Replica Sets are recommended for most use cases over Replication Controllers.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Federated clusters
open_questions.description: What are federated clusters?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are federated clusters?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Federated clusters in Kubernetes are a collection of Kubernetes clusters managed as a single cluster. They enable the management of multiple, geographically distributed clusters as one, providing centralized control while keeping the autonomy of individual clusters. This setup enhances scalability, cross-cluster resource sharing, and high availability across diverse infrastructures.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: You get a static IP for
open_questions.description: How can you get a static IP for a Kubernetes load balancer?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "How can you get a static IP for a Kubernetes load balancer?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: To get a static IP for a Kubernetes load balancer, you typically pre-allocate a static IP in your cloud provider and then specify that IP in the LoadBalancer service configuration in your Kubernetes deployment. This ensures the LoadBalancer uses the designated static IP instead of a dynamic one.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.description: Explain OpenShift.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain OpenShift.?" open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: OpenShift is a container application platform from Red Hat, built on Kubernetes, that provides a cloud-based environment for developing, deploying, and managing containerized applications. It extends Kubernetes with additional features for enterprise use, such as enhanced security, a user-friendly interface, and integrated development tools.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice
